{{Infobox Organization |name = Intersex Campaign for Equality |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = IC4E |motto = |formation = February 2011 |type = [[NGO]] |status = |purpose = [[Intersex]] human rights |headquarters = |location = |region_served = United States |membership = |language = |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = [[Hida Viloria]] |main_organ = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://intersexequality.org/ intersexequality.org] |remarks = }} The '''Intersex Campaign for Equality''' ('''IC4E''') is a [[NGO|non-governmental organization]] that advocates for the [[intersex human rights|human rights of intersex people]].<ref name="mission">{{cite web|title=Our Mission|url=http://www.intersexequality.com/mission/|website= Intersex Campaign for Equality |accessdate=December 17, 2017}}</ref> It was formerly the US affiliate of [[Organisation Intersex International]].<ref name="independent">{{cite web|title = New Mission and Independent Status for IC4E as Viloria resigns from post as OII Chair | url = http://www.intersexequality.com/new-mission-and-independent-status-for-ic4e-as-viloria-resigns-from-post-as-oii-chair/ |date = November 8, 2017 | author = Intersex Campaign for Equality}}</ref>
==History and staff== The Intersex Campaign for Equality was founded as an affiliate of [[Organisation Intersex International]] in February 2011.<ref name="mission" /> The founder and director is author and activist [[Hida Viloria]].<ref name="mission" /><ref name="huffpo-jun2013">{{cite web|author1=Hida Viloria|title=Op-ed: Intersex, the Final Coming-Out Frontier|url=http://www.advocate.com/commentary/2013/06/12/op-ed-intersex-final-coming-out-frontier|website=The Huffington Post|accessdate=January 12, 2017|date=June 12, 2013}}</ref> [[Dana Zzyym]] has been the associate director since February 19, 2015, when intersex activists Dr. Dani Lee Harris, Hida Viloria, and Zzyym re-branded the Intersex Campaign for Equality (IC4E).<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.intersexequality.com/mission/directors/|title=Who We Are|accessdate=December 17, 2017|website=IC4E}}</ref> In November 2017, the Campaign announced their departure from [[Organisation Intersex International]].<ref name="independent" />
==Mission== IC4E aims to campaign for the human rights of [[intersex]] people, particularly rights to self-determination and bodily integrity. It also aims to support intersex individuals, and provide information on the actual life experiences of people with intersex variations to professionals working providing services to them, including medical personnel, psychological experts, sexologists, sociologists and academics.
The Intersex Campaign for Equality is a multi-gendered, multi-orientation, multi-racial NGO founded by and for intersex people.{{cn|date=December 2017}} The Intersex Campaign for Equality's mission is to attain human rights—particularly the rights to bodily integrity, self-determination, legal recognition, and de-pathologization—for all intersex people regardless of sexual orientation, gender identity, race, ability or class, recognizing that some intersex individuals, particularly those with [[nonbinary]] gender identities, remain marginalized even within the intersex community.<ref name="mission" />
==Advocacy== {{Refimprove section|date=January 2017}} IC4E advocates for human rights for intersex people in the United States via personal communication, consulting, public speaking, publishing, and lobbying. The organization also provides peer support, news updates, information, and educational events and lectures. They have lobbied extensively in the press and in print against intersex genital mutilation, aka medically unnecessary "normalizing" genital [[intersex medical interventions|surgeries and hormone treatments]] of intersex infants and minors, and against discriminatory regulations for intersex female athletes.
In 2011, founder and director Hida Viloria lobbied the [[U.S. Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] for inclusion of intersex people, as the "I" in "LGBTI", in LGBT anti-discrimination policies.
=== Physical integrity and bodily autonomy === Attaining the right to physical integrity and bodily determination through an end to the practice of nonconsensual medically unnecessary surgeries on intersex infants and minors--a.k.a. Intersex Genital Mutilation (IGM)--is one of IC4E's founding goals and a primary focus of our education and advocacy work. In 2012, IC4E called for an end to IGM as participants of the Second [[International Intersex Forum]] in Stockholm. In addition, upon suggestion of our participating representative [[Hida Viloria]], Forum participants called for IGM to be framed as human rights issue. This was done in an open letter authored by Viloria<ref>[https://www.ilga-europe.org/sites/default/files/Attachments/hrd_2012_-_intersex_forum_-_un_navil_pillay_letter.pdf Open Letter: A Call for the Inclusion of Human Rights for Intersex People], ILGA Europe, 10 December 2012</ref> signed by participants of the Forum and delivered to [[United Nations]] [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]], [[Navi Pillay]]. In 2013, Viloria served as the sole American co-organizer of the Third [[International Intersex Forum]] in Malta, which culminated in the creation of the [[Malta declaration (International Intersex Forum)]], the most widely agreed upon list of human rights demands--including an end to IGM--by the global intersex community.{{cn|date=December 2017}}
In addition, IC4E team members have been advocating individually, since for IC4E's founding, for an end to IGM. Southesstern Regional Rep. Dr. Dani Lee Harris, of Atlanta, has been educating and advocating for an end to IGM for years via lectures in his Southern Baptist community, and did so in the 2012 intersex documentary ''Intersexion''. Associate Director Dana Zzyym has been advocating against IGM for many years as a college lecturer, and also in the mainstream media, including interviews on ABC NEWS, since filing their groundbreaking lawsuit for a non-binary U.S. passport on [[Intersex Awareness Day]], October 26, 2015, with [[Lambda Legal]] as their legal representative. (The case is still pending as of December, 2017.){{cn|date=December 2017}}
Founding E.D. Hida Viloria has been advocating against IGM since 1996 via numerous television, film and radio interviews. S/he has also published extensively on the issue, discussing opposition to IGM in the majority of her numerous published essays,<ref name="Hida Viloria Bibliography">[http://hidaviloria.com/wp-content/uploads/Hida-Viloria-Bibliography-3.pdf Hida Viloria Bibliography], HidaViloria.com. Retrieved 13 December 2017.</ref> as well as specifically in essays in the ''[[Narrative Inquiry in Bioethics]]'',<ref>[http://narrativebioethics.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Voices_2016_INTERSEX_FINAL.pdf Promoting Health and Social Progress by Accepting and Depathologizing Benign Intersex Traits], ''Narrative Inquiry in Bioethics'',''VOICES: Personal Stories from the Pages of NIB'', "Normalizing Intersex," Issue 2, 2016, p. 29.</ref> ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]],''<ref name="advocate-sep2013">{{cite web|author1=Hida Viloria|title=Op-ed: Why We Must Protect Intersex Babies|url=http://www.advocate.com/commentary/2013/09/27/op-ed-why-we-must-protect-intersex-babies|website=The Advocate|accessdate=January 12, 2017|date=September 27, 2013}}</ref> and ''[[CNN]].com.''.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2009/HEALTH/09/18/hida.viloria.intersex.athlete/index.html Commentary: My Life as a Mighty Hermaphrodite], ''CNN.com'', 18 September 2009.</ref> In addition, Viloria provided expert testimony, in Spanish, in 2013 for the Spanish language television court show ''[[Caso Cerrado]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wgRRWC4i28o|title=Bebé intersexual #700 (3 3) Caso Cerrado|author=justices1989|date=October 15, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2017|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> and was interviewed on ''[[BBC World Service]]'' radio twice: in May, regarding the ground-breaking U.S. lawsuit by the parents of an intersex child against the doctors that operated on him as an infant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p0188d3z|title=Newshour, Dealing with Syria|publisher=BBC World Service|date=May 16, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> Ending IGM is a primary topic of he/r memoir, ''Born Both: An Intersex Life'', the first book by an openly intersex person to be published by a [[Big Five (publishers)|Big Five]] publishing house, [[Hachette Book Group]], in 2017.
=== Third Gender Identification documents === On [[Intersex Awareness Day]], October 26, 2015, Associate Director Dana Zzyym made history by announcing that they, along with their legal representatives from [[Lambda Legal]], the U.S.'s oldest LGBT legal rights organization, are suing the [[United States Department of State]] for legal gender recognition on their passport as someone who is neither male nor female. Zzyym was born intersex and identifies as non-binary and is seeking accurate federal gender recognition.
The lawsuit received extensive coverage in national venues such as ''[[The Washington Post]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/federal-eye/wp/2015/10/27/intersex-applicants-face-passport-discrimination-says-lawsuit-seeking-option-other-than-m-or-f/|title=Intersex applicants face passport discrimination, says lawsuit seeking option other than ‘M’ or ‘F’|author=Lisa Rein|publisher=The Washington Post|date=October 27, 2015|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> ''[[The Huffington Post]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/intersex-veteran-passport_us_562f8076e4b0c66bae5962e1|title=Intersex Navy Veteran Sues State Department For Denying Passport|author=Keith Coffman|date=October 27, 2015|publisher=The Huffington Post}}</ref> ''CNN.com'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/23/us/veteran-intersex-passport-lawsuit/index.html|title=Intersex veteran sues over passport denial|author=Salim Essaid|publisher=CNN|date=July 23, 2016|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> ''The New York Times'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nytlive.nytimes.com/womenintheworld/2016/07/22/intersex-person-dana-zzyym-denied-passport-sues-u-s-government/|title=Intersex person Dana Zzyym denied passport, sues U.S. government|date=July 22, 2016|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-intersex-lawsuit-20160720-snap-story.html|title=Intersex person who was denied a passport over gender designation sues U.S. government|author=Hailey Branson-Potts|publisher=The Los Angeles Times|date=July 20, 2016|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> ''The Advocate'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/travel/2015/10/27/intersex-veteran-denied-passport-refusing-choose-gender-files-lawsuit|title=Intersex Veteran Denied Passport For Refusing to Choose Gender, Files Lawsuit|author=Elizabeth Daley|date=October 27, 2015|publisher=The Advocate|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> and many more, bringing widespread mainstream attention to the existence of, and the need for equal rights for, intersex people.
Articles specifically focusing on intersex birth registrations by Hida Viloria can be found at ''The Advocate''<ref name="advocate-nov2013">{{cite web|author1=Hida Viloria|title=Op-ed: Germany’s Third-Gender Law Fails on Equality|url=http://www.advocate.com/commentary/2013/11/06/op-ed-germany%E2%80%99s-third-gender-law-fails-equality|website=The Advocate|accessdate=January 12, 2017|date=November 6, 2013}}</ref> and ''The Global Herald''.<ref name="herald-nov2013">{{cite web|author1=Hida Viloria |title=Germany’s Third Gender Law: Not What Intersex People Most Need |url=http://theglobalherald.com/germanys-third-gender-law-intersex-people-need/31095/ |website=The Global Herald |accessdate=January 12, 2017 |date=November 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116155044/https://theglobalherald.com/germanys-third-gender-law-intersex-people-need/31095/ |archivedate=January 16, 2017 |df= }}</ref> In November 2013, Viloria was interviewed regarding Germany's third gender law for intersex infants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p01kb0c3|title=Germany Intersex;Pakistan Taliban leader reported dead, World Have Your Say|publisher=BBC World Service|date=November 1, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> In 2014, Viloria provided an introduction to intersex on ''[[HuffPost Live|Huffington Post Live]]'', in November 2013.<ref>[http://live.huffingtonpost.com/r/segment/is-being-intersex-a-third-gender/527167872b8c2a470e000166 Is being intersex a third gender?], Huffington Post Live, in 2013 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207211011/http://live.huffingtonpost.com/r/segment/is-being-intersex-a-third-gender/527167872b8c2a470e000166 |date=2013-12-07 }}</ref>
===Access to sport=== Hida Viloria has experience in advising the International Olympic Committee on intersex perspectives in access to sport.<ref>[http://oii.org.au/7291/bay-area-reporter-iocs-unkind-cuts/ The IOC's unkind cuts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212231103/http://oii.org.au/7291/bay-area-reporter-iocs-unkind-cuts/ |date=2013-12-12 }}, Roger Brigham, [[Bay Area Reporter]], March 11, 2010.</ref><ref name="dx.doi.org">{{cite journal|author1=Hida Patricia Viloria|author2=Maria Jose Martínez-Patino|title=Reexamining Rationales of "Fairness": An Athlete and Insider's Perspective on the New Policies on Hyperandrogenism in Elite Female Athletes|date=2012|volume=12|issue=7|pages=17–19|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/15265161.2012.680543|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref><ref>[http://theglobalherald.com/opinion-gender-rules-in-sport-leveling-the-playing-field-or-reversed-doping/14837/ Gender Rules in Sport – Leveling The Playing Field, Or Reversed Doping?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514122301/http://theglobalherald.com/opinion-gender-rules-in-sport-leveling-the-playing-field-or-reversed-doping/14837/ |date=2013-05-14 }}, Hida Viloria, The Global Herald, April 11, 2010.</ref> With Spanish hurdler Maria José Martínez-Patiño,<ref name="si-sep2009">{{cite web|author1=David Epstein|title=Well, Is She Or Isn't She?|url=https://www.si.com/vault/2009/09/07/105854299/well-is-she-or-isnt-she|website=Sports Illustrated|accessdate=January 12, 2017|date=September 7, 2009}}</ref> Viloria has argued that Olympic sex testing is applied in a way that targets only "[[butch and femme|butch]]" women, those who are "masculine looking".<ref name="dx.doi.org"/> On International Human Rights Day 2013, Hida Vilora spoke as director of IC4E at the [[United Nations]] event, "Sport Comes Out Against Homophobia".<ref name="untv-dec2013">{{cite web|title=Sport Comes Out Against Homophobia|url=http://webtv.un.org/watch/sport-comes-out-against-homophobia/2920436290001/#full-text|website=UN Web TV|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=January 12, 2017|date=December 10, 2013}}</ref><ref name="unnews-dec2013">{{cite web|title=At UN human rights event, Navratilova and Collins decry homophobic violence|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=46706&Cr=homophobia&Cr1=#.WHgmD5KSNrV|website=UN News Centre|accessdate=January 12, 2017|date=December 10, 2013}}</ref>
On [[Human Rights Day]] 2013, Viloria spoke at the United Nations, educating about the human rights violations intersex people face and the need for legal protection from discrimination at the event, "Sport Comes Out Against Homophobia".<ref name="outright-dec2013">{{cite web|title=International Human Rights Day 2013: Sport Comes Out Against Homophobia|url=https://www.outrightinternational.org/content/international-human-rights-day-2013-sport-comes-out-against-homophobia|website=[[OutRight Action International]]|accessdate=January 12, 2017|date=December 10, 2013}}</ref><ref name="pr-dec2013">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/pr/1645169|title=Free & Equal Releases Video of Landmark Event Featuring United Nations Leaders, Sports Stars and LGBT and Intersex Activists|publisher=Digital Journal|date=December 17, 2013|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref>
In addition, in early 2010, before founding the organization, Viloria lobbied the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) for equal treatment of intersex female athletes after the gender verification testing of South African track star [[Caster Semenya]]. This resulted in h/er participating, by invitation, at the IOC 's 2010 meeting of experts in Lausanne, Switzerland, where s/he lobbied that intersex female athletes be allowed to compete as is, without having to undergo unnecessary medical treatments, and that the use of the pathologizing term "disorders of sex development"/DSD to describe these athletes be discontinued.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
In 2014, Viloria spoke about discrimination against intersex female athletes on [[Aljazeera]]'s ''[[The Stream]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://stream.aljazeera.com/story/201409031709-0024124|title=No games for women with 'too much' testosterone|date=September 2, 2014|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref>
===Media and visibility work=== Founder and Director Hida Viloria is one of the first individuals in the world to come out publicly as intersex, via numerous television, film and radio interviews beginning in 1996. He/r media and visibility work includes appearances on such high-profile television programs as ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'', [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''20/20'', and ''[[The Tyra Banks Show]]'', reaching an estimated 100 million viewers via broadcast and additional [[YouTube]] views.
Since founding the organization in 2011, Viloria has published extensively on intersex issues, in publications such as ''[[The American Journal of Bioethics]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Daily Beast]]'', ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', ''The Global Herald'', ''[[Ms.]]'', ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'', and many more.<ref name="Hida Viloria Bibliography"/>
In 2015, on October 26, Intersex Awareness Day, IC4E Associate Director Dana Zzyym announced the filing of their groundbreaking lawsuit for a non-binary U.S. passport. The case has garnered widespread attention by the mainstream media, including ''ABC News, The Washington Post, The Washington Blade,'' and many others, and is expected to continue to as it develops (case still pending as of December 2017).
In March, 2017, E.D. Viloria became the first openly intersex author to be published by one of the [[Big Five (publishers)|Big Five]] publishers, [[Hatchette Book Group]], with the release of he/r memoir, ''Born Both: An Intersex Life''.<ref name="bornboth-hachette">{{cite web|title=Born Both |url=https://www.hachettebookgroup.com/titles/hida-viloria/born-both/9780316347846/ |website=Hachette Book Group |accessdate=January 12, 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204004719/https://www.hachettebookgroup.com/titles/hida-viloria/born-both/9780316347846/ |archivedate=February 4, 2017 |df= }}</ref> S/he has subsequently been featured in interviews in ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', ''[[Psychology Today]]'', and [[NPR]]. The memoir has garnered widespread attention by the mainstream media, including praise in the ''[[New York Times]], [[The Washington Post]]'', and numerous other venues, and selections by ''[[People Magazine]]'' as one of six Best New Books,<ref>[http://www.intersexequality.com/intersex-memoir-praised-in-the-new-york-times-washington-post-more/ Intersex memoir praised in the New York Times, Washington post, and more], Intersex Campaign for Equality, 31 May 2017.</ref> [[School Library Journal]] as one of ten best adult books for teens,<ref>[http://www.slj.com/2017/09/collection-development/adult-books-for-teens/physics-fears-female-empowerment-adult-books-4-teens/#_Physcism Fears, & Female Empowerment: Adult Books 4 Teens], ''School Library Journal'', 13 September 2017.</ref> and more.
=== Publications === On [[Intersex Awareness Day]], October 26, 2012, the organization published the free educational resource ''Brief Guidelines for Intersex Allies''.<ref name="allies">{{cite web|title=Brief Guidelines for Intersex Allies|url=http://www.intersexequality.com/information-intersex-allies/|website=IC4E|accessdate=January 12, 2017|date=October 25, 2012}}</ref> In May 2013, IC4E published ''Your Beautiful Child: Information for Parents'', a resource of non-stigmatizing information for parents, authored by Viloria, which includes links to unbiased medical studies regarding medically unnecessary surgeries for intersex people,<ref name="child">{{cite web|title=Your Beautiful Child: Information for Parents|url=http://www.intersexequality.com/information-for-parents-2/|website=IC4E|accessdate=December 17, 2017|date=May 16, 2013}}</ref> and is being utilized by health care providers around the world.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
In 2015, IC4E assisted{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} the [[United Nations Free & Equal|United Nations Free & Equal Campaign]] in drafting their resource, the Intersex Fact Sheet,<ref name="un-lgbtrights">{{cite web|title=LGBT Rights: Frequently Asked Questions|url=https://unfe-uploads-production.s3.amazonaws.com/unfe-7-UN_Fact_Sheets_v6_-_FAQ.pdf|website=Free & Equal|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> and in 2016, Viloria's essay, "What's in A Name: Intersex and identity", which calls for a non-stigmatizing, equality based linguistic approach to discussing intersex people, was published in the college curriculum textbook, ''Queer: A Reader for Writers'', by [[Oxford University Press]].<ref name="oxford-queer">{{cite web|title=Queer: A Reader for Writers|url=http://www.oxfordpresents.com/readers/book_detail.php?isbn13=9780190277109|website=Oxford University Press|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref>
=== International work === IC4E has also been heavily involved in the international intersex human rights movement. On [[Human Rights Day]], December 10, 2012, founder and director Hida Viloria spearheaded a global call for human rights by and for intersex people, via the "Open Letter: A Call for the Inclusion of Human Rights for Intersex People",<ref name="ilga-dec2012">{{cite web|author1=Hida Viloria|title=Open Letter: A Call for the Inclusion of Human Rights for Intersex People|url=http://www.ilga-europe.org/sites/default/files/hrd_2012_-_intersex_forum_-_un_navil_pillay_letter_2012.pdf|website=ILGA Europe|accessdate=January 12, 2017|date=December 10, 2012}}</ref> which s/he authored and delivered to the [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] with participants of the 2nd [[International Intersex Forum]] in Stockholm signing on in support. The following year, Viloria served as one of three intersex participants chosen by [[ILGA-Europe]] to co-organize the third [[International Intersex Forum]], in Malta, which led to the creation of the Malta Declaration, an internationally agreed declaration of the demands and human rights goals of the international intersex community.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
== Affiliations == IC4E is a member of the [[International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex Association]].{{cn|date=December 2017}}

{{more footnotes|date=April 2015}} [[File:Rithal_village_hariyana_rohtak_0080.jpg|thumb|240px|right|Johad at Rithal village of [[Rohtak district]] of [[Haryana]]]] A '''johad''' ({{Lang-hi|जोहड}}) is a community-owned traditional [[Rainwater harvesting|harvested rainwater]] [[storage tank|storage]] [[wetland]] principally used for [[Water resources in India|effectively harnessing water resources]] in the state of [[Harayana]], [[Rajasthan]], [[Punjab]], western [[Uttar Pradesh]] of [[North India]], that collects and stores water throughout the year, to be used for the purpose of [[Groundwater recharge|recharging the groundwater]] in the nearby [[water well]]s, washing, bathing and [[Water supply and sanitation in India|drinking by humans and cattle]].<ref name=Joh1>Haruka Yanagisawa, 2015, [https://books.google.com.sg/books?isbn=9971698536 Community, Commons and Natural Resource Management in Asia:]</ref><ref name=Joh2>[https://scroll.in/article/715676/video-how-indias-water-man-first-revived-a-river-and-a-village-in-rajasthan Video: How India's 'Water Man' first revived a river and a village in Rajasthan], Scroll.in, 23 Mar 2015.</ref><ref name=Joh3>Amanda Suutari and Gerry Marten, [http://www.ecotippingpoints.org/our-stories/indepth/india-rajasthan-rainwater-harvest-restoration-groundwater-johad.html Water Warriors: Rainwater Harvesting to Replenish Underground Water (Rajasthan, India)], Jun 2015.</ref><ref name=Joh4>Margaret Robertson, 2007, [https://books.google.com.sg/books?isbn=0864314388 Sustainable Futures: Teaching and Learning: a Case Study Approach].</ref> Some johads also have bricked or stones masonry and cemented [[ghat]] (series of steps and/or ramp).<ref name=Joh1/><ref name=Joh2/><ref name=Joh4/>
Johads also cater to resident and seasonal [[Bird migration|migrant birds]] as well as wildlife from the nearby [[Forest|bani]] (forest). [[Fishery Survey of India|State fisheries departments]] also promote the use of these johads for [[Fisheries management|raising fishes]] on contract basis for [[Fishing in India|commercial fishing]]. Johads are often seen surrounded by embankment, with water well and trees around them. In many parts, [[Climate of Rajasthan|specially in dry state of Rajasthan]], the annual rainfall is very low (between 450 and 600 mm) and the water can be unpleasant to drink. Rainfall during July and August is stored in johads and used throughout the year. Johad in [[Haryanvi language]] and [[Rajasthani language]] are also called ''sarovar'', ''taal'' and ''talab'' in [[Hindi Language|Hindi language]], and water pond or lake in English. Johads are called as ''khadin'' in [[Jaisalmer district]]. Over 4,500 working johads in [[Alwar district]] and surrounding districts Rajasthan were revived by the NGO [[Tarun Bharat Sangh]] by [[Rajendra Singh]]. Haryana formed the Haryana State Waterbody Management Board to rejuvenate and manage 14,000 ponds in the state, including the development of 60 lakes in Delhi NCR falling within the state.<ref name=HarWater1/><ref name=HarWater2/>
Smaller cemented [[water tank]]s called ''tanki'' or ''tanka'' in parts of Rajasthan are also sometimes mistakenly referred to as johad. Concretised rain-fed ''tanka'' and canal-fed ''diggi'' are different from the johads.
==Johad wetlands== ===Construction=== Johads can be of several types, such as dug out in areas to which rainwater can be easily channeled. Alternatively, simple mud and rubble barrier [[check dam]]s may be built across the contour of a slope with a high embankment on the three sides while the fourth side is left open for the rainwater to enter. These catch and conserve rainwater, leading to improved percolation and groundwater recharge. They are very common in most villages of states of [[Haryana]], [[Rajasthan]], [[Uttar Pradesh]] and the [[Thar desert]] of Rajasthan in India.<ref name=Joh1/><ref name=Joh2/><ref name=Joh3/><ref name=Joh4/>
===Haryana Johads rejuvenation=== [[File:Rithal village hariyana rohtak 0002.jpg|thumb|240px|left|Johad at Rithal village of [[Rohtak district]] of [[Haryana]]]]
In 2007, [[Haryana Irrigation Department]] spent INR435.26 crore (INR4.3 billion or US$7 million) to renovate and restore water bodies in the state for the conservation of water, recharging of ground water, preservation of environment and enhancement of tourism.<ref name=har1>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2007/20070507/haryana.htm|title=The Tribune, Chandigarh, India - Haryana|website=www.tribuneindia.com}}</ref> A study by the [[Panjab University]] found 60 fish species of 19 families, 11 commercial and 6 exotic species, in the water bodies of Haryana.<ref name=har2>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2006/20060908/haryana.htm#5|title=The Tribune, Chandigarh, India - Haryana|website=www.tribuneindia.com}}</ref> Water bodies remain under risk from encroachment, shrinking of catchment area and pollution.<ref name=har3>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2010/20100730/harplus.htm|title=The Tribune, Chandigarh, India - Haryana Plus|website=www.tribuneindia.com}}</ref> In 2010, India's first ever [[diatom]] data basing was done in ten different water bodies at ten different stations in Haryana.<ref name=har4>{{cite web|url=https://www.lap-publishing.com/catalog/details//store/ru/book/978-3-659-21699-2/diatoms-atlas-of-fresh-waters-bodies-from-haryana-india|title=Diatoms Atlas of Fresh Waters Bodies from Haryana (India) / 978-3-659-21699-2 / 9783659216992 / 3659216992|website=www.lap-publishing.com}}</ref> A 2015 study of 24 water bodies of Haryana, found 39 morphologically different types of diatoms.<ref name=har5>{{cite web|url=http://anilaggrawal.com/ij/vol_017_no_001/papers/paper002/Paper.pdf|title=MORPHOLOGICAL STUDY OF DIATOMS IN 24 DIFFERENT WATER BODIES OF HARYANA, INDIA, Journal of Forensic and Texicology, Saini and Kushwaha, 2016, vol 16, number 1|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2016, the [[Government of Haryana]] announced a plan to map the district-wise map of water flow and to create a database of all water bodies within the state.<ref name=har6>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/haryana-plans-district-wise-maps-of-water-flow-116010600631_1.html|title=Haryana plans district-wise maps of water flow|first=Press Trust of|last=India|date=6 January 2016|publisher=|via=Business Standard}}</ref> These water bodies have contributed to the economic development through fisheries in the landlocked state of Haryana. Haryana ranks second in India in terms of the average annual fish production per unit area in the country with 7000 kg per hectare average annual fish production.<ref name=har7>[harfish.gov.in/development-fisheries.htm Haryana fisheries annual production average, July 2016]</ref> Fish production has increased from 600 tonne in 1966-67 at the time of formation of Haryana to 121000 tonnes of fish during the year 2015-16, providing a livelihood to over 30000 families in fisheries sector.<ref name=har8>{{cite web|url=http://harfish.gov.in/haryana-fisheries.htm|title=Haryana fisheries, July 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
On 1 November 2017, [[Chief Minister of Haryana]] [[Manohar Lal Khattar]] announced that [[Government of Haryana]] will form the [[Haryana State Waterbody Management Board]] <!-- NOTE: Per wiki guidelines, retain limited number of REDLINKS to encourage creation --> to rejuvenate and manage 14,000 ponds in Haryana by digging the silt out every year. This includes development of 50 to 60 lakes in [[National Capital Region (India)|National Capital Region]] falling within the Haryana state.<ref name=HarWater1>[http://indianexpress.com/article/chandigarh/haryana-to-develop-50-60-small-lakes-water-bodies-in-ncr-manohar-lal-khattar-4918316/ "Haryana to develop 50-60 small lakes, water bodies in NCR: Manohar Lal Khattar"], [[Indian Express]], 1 November 2017.</ref><ref name=HarWater2>[http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/haryana-to-constitute-pond-management-authority-117110101271_1.html "Haryana to constitute pond management authority "], [[Business Standard]], 1 November 2017.</ref>
===Rajasthan Johads rejuvenation=== [[File:Rajendra_Singh_interacting_with_Teri_University_Students.JPG|thumb|left|[[Rajendra Singh]], founder of [[Tarun Bharat Sangh]] NGO explaining the use of Johad to the students of [[TERI University]] in [[Alwar district]] of [[Rajasthan]]]]
There was a severe drought in [[Alwar district]] in Rajasthan during 1985-86. In 1985, volunteers from the [[Tarun Bharat Sangh]] (TBS), a voluntary organization led by [[Rajendra Singh]], came to [[Alwar]]. The Alwar District had once thrived, but logging, mining, and other industrial activities resulted in land degradation that intensified flooding and droughts. The traditional water management system using Johads was abandoned. TBS revived the tradition of building Johads, an example of traditional technology that provided water for use and recharging ground water. Now smaller cemented Johads are popularly known as Tankas in most parts of the arid state of Rajasthan.<ref>{{cite news |title=50 people who could save the planet |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/jan/05/activists.ethicalliving |publisher=[[The Guardian]] |date=January 5, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Unquiet flows the water in this village |url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/04/15/stories/2005041509000500.htm |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date=Apr 15, 2005 }}</ref>
The water revolution spread by tanki and johads in the Alwar district has spread far and wide. Now there are around 5,000 johads all over Rajasthan and this has greatly helped in reducing water shortage and improving water quality.
==Similar water bodies== [[Image:Johad.JPG|thumb|right|View of a ''tanki'' in [[Thathawata]] village in [[Rajasthan]]]]
Following are similar to the Johads but are still distinct types of water bodies with specific differentiating features.
===Tanka=== '''Tanka''' or '''Tanki''' is a rain-fed water storage in the arid areas of the [[Indian subcontinent]], such as [[Rajasthan]], specially in the [[bagar tract]].
===Diggi=== '''Diggi''' is a canal-fed [[Waterworks (disambiguation)|water works]] for rural drinking water supply.<ref name=brink1>August 2010, [http://www.indiawaterportal.org/sites/indiawaterportal.org/files/On%20The%20Brink_Water%20Governance_Yamuna%20River%20Basin_Haryana_PEACE_SPWD_2010.pdf On The brink: Water governance in the Yamuna river basin in Haryana], Society for Promotion of Wastelands Development, [http://www.peaceinst.org PEACE Institute Charitable Trust], page vi.</ref> It is usually a purpose-dug open pond, smaller than the typical johad, often concretised to prevent the water loss.

{{notability|org|date=September 2018}} {{notability|web|date=September 2018}} {{advert|date=September 2018}} {{Underlinked|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox company | logo = MedicineNet Logo.png | logo_size = 200px | name = MedicineNet | foundation = October 1996 | type = Health Information | homepage = [https://www.medicinenet.com MedicineNet.com] | owner = [[WebMD]] Since 2004 }}
'''MedicineNet''' is a medical website that provides detailed information about diseases, conditions, medications and general health.<ref>{{cite web | title=www.medicinenet.com | url=http://www.siteencyclopedia.com/medicinenet.com/ | publisher=Website Encyclopedia | accessdate=2018-01-04}}</ref> MedicineNet.com launched in 1995.<ref>{{cite web | title=MedicineNet (TM) Home Page -- A FREE Medical Reference | url=http://medicinenet.com | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19961017100901/http://www.medicinenet.com/ | archivedate=1996-10-17 | deadurl=unfit | accessdate=2018-01-04}}</ref> William Shiel co-founded MedicineNet and continues today as the Chief Medical Editor.<ref name="stjhs">{{cite web | title=Find a Doctor: William C. Shiel, MD | url=https://www.stjhs.org/find-a-doctor/s/william-c-shiel-md/ | publisher=St. Joseph Health | accessdate=2018-01-04}}</ref> Melissa Stöppler also serves on the MedicineNet Editorial Board<ref>{{cite web | title=Melissa Conrad Stöppler, MD | url=https://www.webmd.com/melissa-conrad-stoppler | publisher=[[WebMD]] | accessdate=2018-01-04}}</ref> and she and Shiel were co editors-in-chief of ''Webster's New World Medical Dictionary'', Year 2008, Third Edition.<ref name="stjhs"/><ref>{{cite book | title=Webster's New World Medical Dictionary | editors=William C. Shiel, Jr., MD, FACP, FACR, and Melissa Conrad Stöppler, MD. | date=2009 | publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]] | url=https://books.google.com/books/about/?id=iNrjwl5HCF0C | isbn=9780470373439}}</ref>
MedicineNet is an owned and operated site in the [[WebMD]] Consumer Network<ref>{{cite web | title=WebMD Corporate Site Consumer Network | url=http://www.wbmd.com/servicesconsumer.shtml | publisher=[[WebMD]] | accessdate=2018-01-04}}</ref> and was acquired by WebMD in December 2004.<ref>{{cite web | title=E-Health Market Overview and Internet Health Acquisitions | url=http://www.rightdiagnosis.com/ehealth/e-health-market.htm | date=2015-08-12 | publisher=Right Diagnosis | accessdate=2018-01-04}}</ref> MedicineNet is a network of U.S. Board-Certified Physicians and Allied Health Professionals working together to provide the public with current, comprehensive medical information, written in easy to understand language.<ref name="honcode">{{cite web | title=Certificate of compliance MedicineNet is in compliance with the HONcode | url=https://www.hon.ch/HONcode/Conduct.html?HONConduct594277 | publisher=[[HONcode]] | accessdate=2018-01-04}}</ref>
MedicineNet, as part of the WebMD Consumer Network, adheres to the same privacy policy as WebMD.com and is certified by the TRUSTe online privacy certification program.<ref>{{cite web | title=MedicineNet Privacy Policy | url=https://www.medicinenet.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=12507 | date=2017-12-11 | publisher=MedicineNet | accessdate=2018-01-04}}</ref> In addition, MedicineNet is HONcode certified to be in compliance with the Health on the Net health website principles.<ref name="honcode"/>
MedicineNet is ranked #5 in the July 2017 eBizMBA Top 15 Most Popular Health Websites.<ref>{{cite web | title=Top 15 Most Popular Health Websites July 2017 | url=http://www.ebizmba.com/articles/health-websites | publisher=eBizMBA Inc | accessdate=2018-01-04}}</ref>

Mary "Rae" Morgan (stepmother) |relations = |callsign = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Michele LeAnn Morgan'''{{Cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1996-12-08/news/9612070638_1_death-of-girl-morgan-exhumed|title=Woman Arrested, Charged In 1961 Death Of Girl, 4|website=tribunedigital-orlandosentinel|access-date=2016-04-12}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/12/08/us/a-stepmother-faces-charges-in-1961-death.html|title=A Stepmother Faces Charges In 1961 Death|date=1996-12-08|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-04-12}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1P2-33011759/photo-of-girl-4-could-solve-murder|title="Photo of Girl, 4, Could Solve Murder" by Robert Goodrich Of the Post-Dispatch - St Louis Post-Dispatch (MO), September 2, 1996|website=www.questia.com|access-date=2016-04-12}}{{Cite web|url=https://business.highbeam.com/435553/article-1G1-57259249/woman-charged-61-death-back-illinois|title=WOMAN CHARGED IN '61 DEATH IS BACK IN ILLINOIS.(News)|website=business.highbeam.com|access-date=2016-04-12}}{{Cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1454&dat=19970209&id=Of1OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TRUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6901,2884346&hl=en|title=Star-News - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com|access-date=2016-04-12}} (July 20, 1957 – August 11, 1961) was an American [[child abuse]] victim who was murdered by her stepmother at the age of four. Her story was documented on an episode of ''[[Cold Case Files]]''.{{cite web|title=Watch Through The Eyes Of A Child / Killer Next Door Full Episode - Cold Case Files Classic {{!}} A&E|url=http://www.aetv.com/shows/cold-case-files/season-1/episode-6|website=A&E|accessdate=14 April 2017}}{{cite web|title=Cold Case Files {{!}} Season 1, Episode 6 Through Eyes of a Child; The Killer Next Door|url=http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/cold-case-files/episode-6-season-1/through-eyes-of-a-child-the-killer-next-door/194599/|website=TVGuide.com|accessdate=14 April 2017|language=en}} ==Abuse== Michele suffered multiple injuries to the chest and back, a broken nose, burns on her skin, and a broken arm before the age of four at the hands of her stepmother, Mary Rae. These led to over 20 visits to a hospital, including one in which she was hospitalized for a month.{{cite news|title=Step-daughter died in 1961 Scots motheradmits killing child|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12250369.Step_daughter_died_in_1961_Scots_motheradmits_killing_child/|accessdate=14 April 2017|work=HeraldScotland|publisher=Herald & Times Group|date=29 October 1998|language=en}} ==Murder== On August 9, 1961, Mary held Michele under water and stomped her violently, believing that the child had lied about something. These actions were seen by Michele's older brother, George. At dinner, Michele threw up [[blood clot]]s.{{cite news|title=Stepmother Charged In 1961 Death {{!}} Seattle Times Newspaper|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19961208&slug=2363605|accessdate=14 April 2017|work=Associated Press|publisher=The Seattle Times|date=8 December 1996|location=BELLEVILLE, Ill.}} The next day she died of her internal injuries. An autopsy was conducted by the pathologist at the [[army base]] where the Morgans lived, and the cause of death was found to be massive trauma to the chest. The autopsy report was not completed until 15 years later, when the coroner listed the cause of death as [[pneumonia]]. The local prosecutor never pursued the case. ==Disclosure== In 1996, George Morgan (Michele's older brother) was serving time in prison for [[rape]]. That year, he decided to research his family [[genealogy]] and was surprised when he saw his sister's [[death certificate]]. He recalled the circumstances surrounding her death and was certain that it was not caused by pneumonia — and that it had occurred in 1961, not in 1976.{{cite news|title=Woman Charged in 1961 Slaying of 4-Year-Old Stepdaughter|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1996/Woman-Charged-in-1961-Slaying-of-4-Year-Old-Stepdaughter/id-81af734ab5404dc091e709a71f94b036|accessdate=14 April 2017|work=www.apnewsarchive.com|publisher=Associated Press|date=21 October 1998|location=BELLEVILLE, ILL|language=en}} Morgan then corresponded with County [[Coroner]] Rick Stone and disclosed to him how Michele's death really occurred. Stone subsequently reopened the case and Michele's body was [[Exhumation|exhumed]]. Though the body had been buried for over 30 years, it still showed the marks of brutal child abuse.{{cite news|last1=HUNDSDORFER|first1=BETH|title=Rick Stone, St. Clair County coroner since 1984, dies {{!}} Belleville News-Democrat|url=http://www.bnd.com/news/local/article114375528.html|accessdate=14 April 2017|work=www.bnd.com|date=12 November 2016|language=en}} Investigators discovered the original autopsy report and Michele's hospital record, which showed multiple visits.{{cite news|title=After 35 Years, Stepmother Charged In Murder Of Girl, 4|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1996-12-08/news/9612080221_1_stepmother-mary-morgan-exhumed|accessdate=14 April 2017|work=From Tribune News Services.|publisher=Chicago Tribune|date=8 December 1996|location=BELLEVILLE, ILLINOIS|language=en}} George Morgan's claims were thus substantiated. ==Prosecution== Mary Morgan was tracked down in [[West Columbia, Texas]], and initially denied the allegations leveled against her. She then attempted to flee the country but was caught and placed under arrest. She eventually pleaded guilty to [[involuntary manslaughter]] and was sentenced to five years in prison and was released in 2001. In the years after Michele's death, Mary raised four children. Hospital records showed that the four of them had collectively visited the hospital over 150 times for medical care before the age of five. ==See also== *[[List of murdered American children]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.facebook.com/UnitedWeStandAgainstChildAbuse/photos/a.490100921065847.1073741828.490065944402678/693794894029781/ United We Stand Against Child Abuse] *[https://www.questia.com/read/1P2-33035265/uncovering-answers-in-child-s-death Uncovering Answers in Child's Death] *[http://tv.ark.com/transcript/cold_case_files-(through_the_eyes_of_a_child;_the_killer_next_door)/612/KICU/Tuesday_August_31_2010/429278/ Cold Case Files - Through the Eyes of a Child; The Killer Next Door (transcript)] *{{Find a Grave|6932523|Michele LeAnn Morgan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Morgan, Michele}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:1961 deaths]] [[Category:1961 in Illinois]] [[Category:1961 murders in the United States]] [[Category:Child abuse in the United States]] [[Category:Child abuse resulting in death]] [[Category:Deaths by beating in the United States]] [[Category:History of St. Clair County, Illinois]] [[Category:Murdered American children]] [[Category:People from St. Clair County, Illinois]] [[Category:People murdered in Illinois]] [[Category:Female murder victims]]

'''Murray Elias Jarvik''' (June 1, 1923 – May 8, 2008) was an [[United States|American]] [[psychopharmacology|psychopharmacologist]] and [[academic]] who was among the first scientists to study [[d-lysergic acid]], the precursor to [[LSD]],<ref name=nyt>{{cite news |first=Bruce|last=Weber|title=Murray Jarvik, 84, Whose Research Helped Lead to Nicotine Patch, Dies |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/13/health/13jarvik.html?ref=us |work= [[New York Times]] |publisher= |date=2008-05-13 |accessdate=2008-05-26}}</ref> and later became the co-inventor of the [[nicotine patch]].<ref name=iht>{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Dr. Murray Jarvik, co-inventor of nicotine patch, dies at 84 in Santa Monica |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/05/10/america/NA-GEN-US-Obit-Jarvik.php|work= [[Associated Press]] |publisher= [[International Herald Tribune]]|date=2008-05-10 |accessdate=2008-05-26}}</ref> He was a longtime [[professor emeritus]] at [[University of California-Los Angeles]], where he taught as a professor of [[psychiatry]] and [[pharmacology]] for many years.<ref name=iht/>
== Personal life== Murray Jarvik was born in [[New York City]] on June 1, 1923.<ref name=nyt/> He was the son of Minnie (Haas) and Jacob Jarvik, an [[upholsterer]].<ref name=nyt/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/latimes/obituary.aspx?n=murray-e-jarvik&pid=109390365|title=Murray E. Jarvik's Obituary on Los Angeles Times|website=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref> Jarvik suffered from lifelong heart problems, which began with a severe case of [[rheumatic fever]] when he was twelve years old.<ref name=nyt/> He later developed [[polio]] at the age of 28 and was diagnosed with [[lung cancer]] in 1992, which was cured.<ref name=nyt/> He was never a [[Smoking|smoker]].<ref name=nyt/>
Jarvik received his undergraduate [[bachelor's degree]] at the [[City College of New York]] before earning his [[master's degree]] in science at [[U.C.L.A.]].<ref name=nyt/> He received his [[doctorate]] from the [[University of California, Berkeley]] and his [[Doctor of Medicine|medical degree]] from the [[University of California, San Francisco]].<ref name=nyt/>
He was married to his wife, Dr. Lissy Feingold Jarvik, for 53 years, and the couple had two sons.<ref name=lat>{{cite news |first=Thomas|last=Maugh II|title=Dr. Murray E. Jarvik, 84; UCLA pharmacologist invented nicotine patch |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/california/la-me-jarvik14-2008may14,0,3688594.story|work= [[Los Angeles Times]] |publisher= |date=2008-05-14 |accessdate=2008-05-26}}</ref> His son Laurence Jarvik made the documentary film ''[[Who Shall Live and Who Shall Die]]'' about the inaction of the [[Franklin D. Roosevelt Administration|Roosevelt Administration]] during the time of the [[Holocaust]]. His nephew [[Robert Jarvik]] developed an [[artificial heart]] called [[Jarvik-7]].<ref name=lat/>
== Nicotine patch == Murray Jarvik began research into the [[absorption (skin)|absorption]] of [[tobacco]] contents through the [[Human skin|skin]] and its effects on the [[human body]].<ref name=iht/> His initial exploration into this field began by studying [[farmers]] and [[farmhand]]s in the [[American South]] who harvest tobacco by hand for a living.<ref name=iht/>
However, Jarvik and his colleague, then UCLA [[postdoctoral]] [[fellow]] [[Jed Rose (scientist)|Jed Rose]], could not get approval to conduct their research into tobacco absorption through the skin on human subjects.<ref name=iht/> Instead, Jarvik and Rose began testing the effects of absorption of tobacco contents on themselves.<ref name=iht/> The effects of the tobacco was immediately measurable. In an interview with [[UCLA Magazine]], Jarvik remembered, "We put the tobacco on our skin and waited to see what would happen. Our [[heart rate]]s increased, [[adrenaline]] began pumping, all the things that happen to smokers."<ref name=iht/>
Jarvik and Rose's research led to their invention of the [[nicotine patch]] in the early 1990s.<ref name=nyt/><ref name=iht/> The nicotine patch is a [[transdermal patch]] that delivers [[nicotine]] directly through the [[Human skin|skin]] and into the body to alleviate the urge to smoke and, hopefully, ultimately [[quit smoking]].<ref name=iht/> (Rose now serves as the [[Board of directors|director]] of the Center for Nicotine and Smoking Cessation Research at [[Duke University]].)<ref name=iht/>
The nicotine patch became available by [[Medical prescription|prescription]] for [[smoking cessation]] in the [[United States]] in 1992.<ref name=iht/> The [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) approved its sale as an [[Over-the-counter drug|over-the-counter]] treatment in 1996.<ref name=iht/>
== Death == Murray Jarvik died at his home in [[Santa Monica, California]], on May 8, 2008, at the age of 84 from a [[pulmonary edema]] from [[congestive heart failure]].<ref name=nyt/>

{{Occupational hazards}}
'''Occupational epidemiology''' is a subdiscipline of [[epidemiology]] that focuses on investigations of workers and the workplace.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/SLTC/occupationalepidemiology/index.html|title=Occupational Epidemiology|last=|first=|date=|website=U.S. [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2016-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Research Methods in Occupational Epidemiology|last=Checkoway|first=Harvey|last2=Pearce|first2=Neil|last3=Kriebel|first3=David|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=0-19-509242-2|location=New York, NY|pages=|quote=}}</ref> Occupational epidemiologic studies examine health outcomes among workers, and their potential association with conditions in the workplace including noise, chemicals, heat, or radiation, or work organization such as schedules.
The need for evidence to inform occupational safety regulations, [[workers' compensation]] programs, and safety legislation motivated the development of public health policy, occupational epidemiology methods, and surveillance mechanisms.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Halperin|first=William|last2=Howard|first2=John|date=2011-10-07|title=Occupational Epidemiology and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/su6004a15.htm|journal=[[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]]|publisher=U.S. [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]]|volume=60|pages=97–103|via=}}</ref> Occupational epidemiological research can inform [[risk assessment]]s; development of standards and other risk management activities; and estimates of the co-benefits and co-harms of policies designed to reduce risk factors or conditions that can affect human health. Occupational epidemiology methods are common to methods used in [[environmental epidemiology]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pell|first=S.|date=May 1993|title=Epidemiologists in industry. Past achievements, unexplored opportunities, and future needs|journal=Journal of Occupational Medicine|volume=35|issue=5|pages=485–492|issn=0096-1736|pmid=8515320}}</ref>
== History == [[Occupational hazard]]s have long been recognized. For example, [[Hippocrates]] recommended other physicians consider patients' vocational backgrounds when diagnosing and treating disease, and [[Bernardino Ramazzini]] in 1700 outlined many occupational diseases in his book ''De Morbis Artificum''. There are several examples from the 19th century onwards of hazard recognition proceeding to systematic epidemiology studies. In one example, premature mortality was reported among gold and silver miners in the [[Ore Mountains|Erz Mountains]] in Germany as early as the 16th century.<ref name=":0" /> It was initially though to be the result of [[Tuberculosis|consumption]], but it was subsequently determined to be [[silicosis]], and studies from 1879 through the 1930s uncovered the association of miners' deaths with [[lung cancer]] and nonmalignant [[respiratory disease]]s. Other examples include cancer among chimney sweeps, [[asbestos]]-related diseases, and the variety of occupational diseases found among factory workers in the early 1900s.<ref name=":0" />
Occupational health risks were initially observed by [[case series]] reports of apparent disease excesses or [[Disease cluster|clusters]]. Although the [[case series]] approach provided a good indicator of [[occupational hazard]]s, they are not adequate on their own to assess a wide spectrum of health outcomes that may not be closely related to workplace exposure. The development of retrospective, [[Cohort study|cohort design]] allowed for a more comprehensive study of the cases. Desire to improve the cost-efficiency of studies led to the use of [[Case-control study|case-control studies]]. Other methods later used in occupational epidemiology include [[Cross-sectional study|cross-sectional]] and [[Longitudinal study|longitudinal studies]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/610965808|title=Research methods in occupational epidemiology|last=Checkoway|first=Harvey|last2=Pearce|first2=Neil|last3=Crawford-Brown|first3=Douglas J.|date=|publisher=Oxford University Press|others=|year=1989|isbn=9780195092424|location=New York|pages=5–8, 59, 61, 66, 72, 331|oclc=610965808}}</ref>
== Types of studies ==
=== Case series === Typically occupational epidemiological investigations begin with the observation of an unusual number of cases of disease among a group of workers. When the investigation does not go further than what is referred to as identifying a [[disease cluster]], the study is referred to as a [[case series]] report.<ref name=":0" />
=== Cohort studies === In a [[Cohort study|cohort design study]], a [[Population (statistics)|population]], or cohort, of workers is compared to a [[Treatment and control groups|control group]] that was not exposed to the [[Occupational hazard|workplace hazards]] being investigated. This type of study is the most accepted in the [[scientific community]] because it most closely follows experimental strategy and observes the entire population rather than a sample. In a prospective cohort study, the group examined at the time of the study is compared to a follow up with the same group in the future. The historical cohort study design begins with defining a cohort at a time in the past and following the cohort over historical time.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.agius.com/hew/resource/occepi.htm|title=Occupational Epidemiology|last=Agius|first=Raymond|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-07-30}}</ref>
=== Case-control studies === Case-control studies compare the past exposure of cases with the disease to the past exposure of cases that did not have the disease. Because [[Cohort study|cohort studies]] require the entire [[Population (statistics)|population]], [[Case-control study|case-control studies]] are a more cost-effective approach, using only the sample of workers with the disease to compare to a control.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
=== Cross-sectional studies === A typical [[cross-sectional study]] involves the comparison of varying degrees of exposure and the prevalence of disease, symptoms, or physiological status. The main advantage of cross-sectional studies is that they allow collection of data on conditions which would not be recorded normally because other study designs focus on severe states of disease. This is also the biggest shortcoming of this study type because by using prevalence rather than incidence it cannot be used to make a causal inference.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== Application == By contributing to reduction in exposure, occupational epidemiology helps reduce health risks among workers. Using occupational epidemiological methods can also have benefits for society at large. For example, recommendations for [[Occupational exposure limit|exposure limits]] to [[benzene]] developed by the [[Expert Panel on Air Quality Standards]] were based on occupational epidemiology.<ref name=":1" />
Using [[meta-analysis]], many occupational epidemiology studies can be synthesized in order to help set [[occupational exposure limit]]s and make other kinds of policy decisions. This can also can be applied in health [[risk assessment]]s, which is a method of predicting health risk based on hypothetical exposure conditions.<ref name=":0" />

The '''proportional reporting ratio (PRR)'''<ref>{{cite journal | last=Evans | first=SJ |author2=Waller, PC |author3=Davis,S | year=2001 | volume=10 | title=Use of proportional reporting ratios (PRRs) for signal generation from spontaneous adverse drug reaction reports | pages=483–486 | journal= Pharmacoepidemiol Drug Saf.| doi= 10.1002/pds.677| issue=6 | publisher=Wiley | pmid=11828828}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Matsushita | first=Y |author2=Kuroda, Y |author3=Niwa, S |author4=Sonehara, S |author5=Hamada, C |author6= Yoshimura, I | year=2007 | volume=30 | title=Criteria revision and performance comparison of three methods of signal detection applied to the spontaneous reporting database of a pharmaceutical manufacturer | pages=715–726 | journal= Drug Saf.| doi= 10.2165/00002018-200730080-00008| issue=8 | publisher= | pmid=17696584 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Hauben | first=M | year=2004 | volume=38 | title=Early postmarketing drug safety surveillance: data mining points to consider | journal=Ann Pharmacother | doi= 10.1345/aph.1E023| issue=10 | publisher= | pmid= 15304626 | pages=1625–30}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Banks | first=D |author2=Woo, EJ |author3=Burwen, DR |author4=Perucci, P |author5=Braun, MM |author6= Ball, R | year=2005 | volume=14 | title=Comparing data mining methods on the VAERS database | journal=Pharmacoepidemiology and Drug Safety | doi= 10.1002/pds.1107| issue=9 | publisher= | pmid=15954077 | pages=601–609}}</ref> is a [[statistic]] that is used to summarize the extent to which a particular [[adverse event]] is reported for individuals taking a specific [[drug]], compared to the frequency at which the same adverse event is reported for patients taking some other drug (or who are taking any drug in a specified class of drugs). The PRR will typically be calculated using a surveillance database in which reports of adverse events from a variety of drugs are recorded.
A PRR greater than 1 suggests that the adverse event is more commonly reported for individuals taking the drug of interest, relative to the comparison drugs. This could indicate that the adverse event is caused by the drug of interest and therefore a "side effect", although a PRR exceeding 1 could also reflect sampling variation in the data, reporting errors, biased reporting, multiple reports of the same case or the same patient, or a number of other causes.
The PRR is defined as the ratio between the frequency with which a specific adverse event is reported for the drug of interest (relative to all adverse events reported for the drug) and the frequency with which the same adverse event is reported for all drugs in the comparison group (relative to all adverse events for drugs in the comparison group). For example, suppose that [[nausea]] was reported 83 times for a given drug of interest, out of 1356 adverse events reported for the drug. Thus the proportion of adverse events of nausea for this drug is 83/1356 = 0.061. Suppose that we wish to compare the drug of interest to a class of drugs, for which nausea was reported as an adverse event 1489 times, out of 53789 total adverse events reported for drugs in the class. Thus, nausea was reported with proportion 1489 / 53789 = 0.028 for the class of drugs. The PRR in this case is 0.061 / 0.028 = 2.18. This tells us that nausea was reported more than twice as frequently (among all adverse event reports) for the drug of interest compared to drugs in the comparison group.

'''Radio Malt''' was an early to mid-20th century brand of [[malt]] extract preparation that followed the [[Minadex]] trend.<ref>Newnham, David. (October 23, 2002) [[Nursing Standard]] ''Outside in'' Volume 17; Issue 6; Page 31.</ref> Produced by British Drug Houses, it contained [[vitamin A]], [[Thiamine|aneurine hydrochloride]], [[riboflavin]], and [[calciferol]].<ref>{{cite web|last =|first =|authorlink =|coauthors =|title = Malt Extract (Barley)|work =|publisher = Herbdata New Zealand|year = 2002|url = http://www.herbdatanz.com/malt_extract_(barley)__usd1926_picture_mongraph.htm|doi =|accessdate = 2007-09-25 }}</ref> The contents were sickly sweet, with a consistency between [[molasses]] and [[treacle]]. It is much loved by George Molesworth ("Molesworth 2"), brother of the classic schoolboy character [[Nigel Molesworth]].<ref>[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/reader/0141186003?v=search-inside&_encoding=&url=stripsearch&keywords=radio+malt Molesworth] - Page 94,96,241 and 391</ref>
Radio Malt was being sold in the [[UK]] by the mid-1920s<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title = Monthly Memoranda (points for propaganda)| work =| publisher =| date = 1926–1927| url = http://archives.wellcome.ac.uk/DServe/dserve.exe?&dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqDb=Catalog&dsqCmd=Show.tcl&dsqSearch=(RefNo=='WF/M/GB/30/04')| format =| doi =| accessdate = 2007-09-25 }}</ref> and was studied at this time as a treatment for [[rickets]].<ref>{{Cite journal| last = Redman| first = Thirza| title = The hydrogen ion concentration and the calcium and phosphorus content of the faeces of rachitic children| journal = Biochemical Journal| volume = 23| issue = 2| pages = 256–260| date =| year = 1929| doi =| id =| pmid = 16744211| pmc = 1254019| postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> In India it was trademarked in 1942.<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title = Register of Trademarks Indexed on Class & TM No. (p.176)| work =| publisher =| date =| url = http://www.patentoffice.nic.in/tmr_new/model_tm/CLASS%20&%20TM%20NO.pdf| format = pdf| doi =| accessdate = }}</ref>
A favourite of film producer and politician [[David Puttnam]],<ref>Freud, Clement. (February 6, 1993) [[The Times]] ''Local hero with a finger in every pie; David Puttnam; Gut Feelings.'' Section: Features; Page SR.</ref> Radio Malt was often used in English boarding schools in an attempt to change skinny young girls into prettier roundness<ref>Davenport, Philippa. (February 10, 1996) [[Financial Times]] ''Food and Drink: Puds to make a Briton proud - Cookery.'' Page IV</ref> and given to post-World War II children to give them more bulk.<ref>Bovey, Shelley. (January 15, 2000) [[The Scotsman]] ''AB Flab.''</ref>
